title: Caring Practice
body: Found everyone helpful even though very busy. Doctors and staff trying to get through as many patients as possible without racing you through

title: Disgrace
body: This surgery was fantastic, i moved out of area but my 94 yr old nana still attends, i notified them at least 7 times via phone (waited stupidly long for someone to answer) she is now housebound, she cant and wont be attending appointments-they said its logged on system for nurses to go to her for covid booster and any blood work or tests etc. Nana got appointment for tests, i called into gp practice and told is wasnt logged but theyd do it- she is still waiting for tests thats now 7wks over due on yearly blood work she has done and no covid booster yet either!!! Yes covid hasnt helped but how long do they expect to use this as an excuse and their staffing issues? Its effecting patients and your reputation

title: Excellent service
body: Visited urgent treatment centre this afternoon, I was seen and treated quickly and efficiently, staff were wonderful, helpful, friendly

title: Great A&E Receptionist
body: She exceeded the required level of service, resolving a genuine issue. This allowed me to enjoy the rest of my weekend away.

title: Very Efficient and Kind Staff
body: I have been under the cardiac surgery team at The Glenfield now for over two years and cannot say enough about how caring they are towards  me. I am always treated with dignity and kindness. During my last out-patients they really took time to explain in detail about the surgery I will be having and they listed me for it. I recently had my last scan and my surgeonâ€™s secretary scheduled my surgery without hesitation when I rang and explained I had increased chest pains. I cannot thank those involved enough.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: Wonderful treatment
body:
All the staff involved in my treatment from consultants, doctors, nurses,physios , A&E and even the cheerful cleaners,were so supportive.
The care and service I received was exemplary.

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: great practice
body: Straight to the point, great services by a great team. brilliant banter in a very professional environment.

title: Great practice
body: A quick and efficient service delivered by nurse gifty. Very Professional and polite. Always a great service given by reception staff and medical staff.

title: Audiology - Fantastic Service
body: Contacted the hospital as I needed new domes - but didn't know how to order. Chief Audiologist called me straight  back, despite being ill and working from home, found out what I needed, let me know how to order and what services were available and answered some other queries I have too. Great customer service, fast, courteous, human. Thank you

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Patronising and negligent
body: My daughter has had severe mental health difficulties for several years now which have resulted in 2 suicide attempt, Self harm and now she is under the ED clinic. We visited the clinic today for a fortnightly appointment after she was rushed to A&E a week ago due to self injury, to be told once again that there is a long waiting list to see the doctors and because she wasnâ€™t engaging the session was terminated half an hour early, and I was offered a parenting course. Iâ€™m am disgusted at this suggestion. She is unwell, and I need to go on a course to be a better parent. She was beside herself after the session telling me that she wanted to end her life. What exactly are you doing to support my daughter. I will not rest until she gets the support she deserves. And she is seen as unwell. Not just another problematic statistic.

readBy.name: Avon and Wiltshire Mental Health Partnership NHS Trust

title: Inadequate mental health care
body:
After suffering several years with mental health issues fobbed off by gp & local mh services recently admitted following manic episode & attempted suicide Taken to worthing a&e early morning. Promises of assistance & admission to mh facility to stabilise condition but kept in bay until nearly 9pm & then discharged with no support or advice.
Nhs talk a lot about mental health care provision but the truth seems to be that they don't really care & are inept at dealing with it.

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Mental health issues
body: I have had only had ,I think only one face too face appointment in the last 2 years,I have never been asked how I am doing,how is the medication working,nothing at all, I must say my medication is not doing nothing for me,I'm sooh depressed I want to give up. Why don't you follow up, on the people who come for help.  I have never been asked (a)how have I been since the last appointment, (b)how is the medication,how is your mood. The answer to those questions no I have heard nothing nothing from Osborne House at all. I feel  I don't get any help from them nothing at all.

title: Rubbish service. Dr's just don't care.
body: Had an appointment booked for 4:40, at 5:30 I was still waiting to be seen. Apparently the referral for the appointment hadn't even gone through to the Dr I was seeing. I was told the Dr was going to do examinations and referrals to get Me some help with my condition but all he did was take my blood pressure and prescribed me some medication which I could have just got over the phone. I go to both St James's and old field park surgery, both lack any care for patients, waiting times are ridiculous, you spend an hour waiting just to be in with the Dr for 5 minutes. Every time you ring the surgeries your on hold for hours at a time. You never get to see the same Dr twice so long term illnesses are always having to be reexplained, it's just a revolving door of Dr's. Heart of bath was a terrible idea, the NHS is failing. Dr's don't care anymore your just another number to them.

author: alpharx76
title: Upsetting experience
body:
I have been having investigations done and am very worried about my health. My GP who has been excellent contacted me with some results and advised I needed further investigations. They also arranged for me to attend the treatment room for blood tests.  
I was a few minutes late for the appointment time and was very rudely informed of this by a member of staff who met me. I was very embarrassed by the way they spoke to me in front of other patients it also made me very anxious. They also suggested that they may not be able to honour my appointment.  
They did bring me in and took my blood and once again spoke to me in a manner which was very upsetting telling me that a bit of advice if you have an appointment time make sure I am on time. I asked could I leave as the staff member was so rude and making me very anxious and upset and they said yes and continued to add that they could very easily have turned me away.  
After I'd left the surgery my arm started to bleed and I had a large lump afterwards and have badly bruised for a week now.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: silverwaredg74
title: Great service from leg ulcer clinic
body:
At last I have finally been treated for my leg ulcer, after trying to get a face to face appointment with one of the GPs at my GP practice since Christmas time. The new young doctors are pleasant enough and were willing to see me but trying to get to see a GP has been impossible. I get asked to send in photo but no face to face appointment offered.  
The nurses and receptionists and chemist attached are great and eventually after 6 months the nurses referred me to the leg ulcer clinic at Bideford Hospital.  
The high quality of care from staff at the leg ulcer clinic have been wonderful. The clinic is very 'old school' and reminds me of how care and the NHS used to be. The nurses and staff in charge are lovely even the receptionist and the cleaner are fantastic.  
I truly hope we don't lose this clinic from Bideford like we did with the A&E. Living in a tourist location can get very busy in services during peak times of the year and we need these smaller services.  
I feel that if I had been seen by one of the GPs from the beginning it would not have got as bad as it did. Sometimes a face to face appointment is absolutely necessary.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: waltztf79
title: GP surgery using Physician Associates
body:
I have been with the Lawson Practice for many years however have recently found out that sadly the practice are now employing Physician Associates. This is an issues as when booking to speak with a GP, calls are being taken by Physician Associates instead - not at the request of the patients.  
A recent BBC Panorama Investigation highlighted the over-reliance on Physician Associates and their unwarranted use as GP substitutes and the Investigation raised many concerns, causing the Quality Care Commission to launch their own investigation.  
The GP commentators questioned whether this business model was not posing real safety risks for patients, with PAs being used wrongly as cheap substitutes for trained GPs  
My experience with dealing with a Physician Associate at The Lawson Practice has led to a wrong / incorrect referral being made, which has caused delays in obtaining diagnostics.  
This has led to more calls happening between the Practice and myself, further appointments made to speak with a GP - This creates unnecessary pressures on the service and does not cut down on wait times or free up appointments.  
I feel this this is an example of profit being put before care.

author: ayesha0509
title: 111 cant give me dental appointment
body: I have just tried to make an appointment via NHS 111 service to be told they cannot make an electronic referral at this time and that I should self present at BDH which is contrary to the instructions on the dental hospital website. I have a fully broken tooth with jagged edges and all the symptoms of a painful abscess forming and on antibiotics. I have been calling everyday for last 5 days. They have sent me to local dentist who said we can only send referral can't help with emergency appointment it's very confusing information what do I do

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: SBT1989
title: Effective care but communication lacking
body:
I attended maternity triage late one evening with pain and was initially assessed by an excellent student midwife on the labour ward who explained each step and put my mind at ease. The doctor who was on shift was equally attentive, and explained her clinical reasoning throughout. I fortunately got home that evening and returned the following day for a CTPA.  
The following day I attended the ward I was advised to attend via telephone but they weren't expecting me nor had anywhere for me to be cannulated or change prior to my scan - as a result I missed my original CT appointment. I was instead sent down to maternity triage none the wiser about what was happening. The senior charge nurse in triage also wasn't expecting me, but she was fantastic and took control of the situation and luckily got my scan rebooked, cannulated me and got me prepped within a matter of minutes.  
Thanks to her quick action I attended the scan and got the all clear within 90 minutes of being sent down to triage. Overall the care was excellent, but the lack of clear communication could have delayed the scan and impacted on my care.

author: aquilacw75
title: Not taken seriously and left feeling not understood
body:
When I first booked an appointment I was told I had to wait another week before being seen despite the problem I have the symptoms being really discomforting so was advised to get a Particular medicine to help treat it. So when the appointment arrived a week later my symptoms were a lot better as the medication advised by the nurse on the telephone app cleared it up.  
At my face to face appointment when I was discussing my problem with the nurse, as I had mentioned I looked online to get self medicated as I have had this problem reoccurring I felt like I was shut down as if I was a hypochondriac and told not to look online and that I shouldâ€™ve rang when I had the symptoms and to not take any medication until I get seen by someone - I said I did call up and that I was actually advised by a fellow nurse to take medication so what am I meant to do, just suffer with my symptoms for another week whilst waiting for my appointment and listen to you or listen to the nurse I had my telephone appointment with?!  
It was conflicting advice I was being given and I felt patronised when the member of staff kept saying stop looking online. I understand some people may be hypochondriacs and be paranoid about what they have however I know my body and this has happened before whereby no one would take me seriously until I received an official diagnosis despite I had been saying for months I had what I was eventually diagnosed with.  
The nurse and doctor who saw me donâ€™t know me and I know when something isnâ€™t right and the medication I actually took as advised by the nurse on the telephone appointment treated the problem I think I have so Iâ€™m clearly right in saying I have this problem. They should not judge people by the same page - everyone is individual and different and I was really upset when I left the appointment as I felt I was not taken seriously at all.

author: NDee1973
title: Lack of follow up from dr
body:
Went to doctors about lumps in groin, stomach, swollen feet & dramatic weight loss which am sure was 9kg in 6mnths, so doctor referred me to ecdc to be on safe side & within 1 to 2 weeks I had appointment, I felt nervous but my daughter the staff at ecdc made me feel so at ease talking about everything about why I was referred etc and what was going to happen next etc, which was ct scan & all went ok with that too.  
Appointment again was quick in coming through & results too which made me feel better, my only disappointment is that my own surgery doctor that referred me has never contacted me since been at ecdc about the letter they have sent detailing how I got on at ecdc etc, I have own letter sent to me but just dont know what step is with my own doctor as been 3 or 4 weeks since I was at clinic but still no word from my doctor, but so grateful of everyone at ecdc for been very warm & welcoming with me.

author: Firehunter113
title: Long waiting lists
body: Iâ€™ve tried to receive help for years which has been met with 1-2 year waiting lists which I have never heard back from. The services that have been reccomended are essentially charities with no expert professional psychologist. Some of these services are not able to offer essential treatment for patients as they do not offer certain services. I have given up on the nhs, I am told it is on the brink of collapse and a GP told me that I would be on a long waiting list to see anyone. I'm exceptionally disgusted by the way I was treated by that doctor, if they had said that to someone in a more urgent situation I can imagine that would be enough to send them over the edge. Why am I paying taxes for a health service that is apparently underfunded and cannot help me?

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: GN Belfast
title: Emergency department visit felt grim
body:
After recent phone/online consultations and advice from GP and other assorted 'health professionals', plus some in-person in recent weeks, I was finally persuaded and agreed to go Ulster Hospital ED/A&E due to severe pain and other symptoms hardly-shifted by prescribed painkillers and steadily worsening in intensity recently.  
I limped-in, attendant on door directed me to a hand-sanitiser which didn't work the best; then to get booked-in, which was OK and, while busy, there were plenty of spare seats. I sat down, and triage nurse called me within 30 minutes, she was grand, and said I'd need blood tests, health assistant called me after about another 45 minutes, she was grand too. I anticipated a long, painful wait, so read bits and pieces and just observed the screens and goings-on around me - as you do.  
I noticed how many assorted posters and notices there were about the place, often on A4 and not easy to read - including one for this website, which I noted - and some telling people 'no relatives allowed', which was/is understandable.  
However, the longer I was there, the longer I realised that the practical impact of that was that there were very obviously a number of variously vulnerable people waiting in the reception area, some appearing lost and bewildered, and in some cases visibly quite distressed, with no one seemingly doing anything about it, and this grew worse as time went on. It was also clear that such people had little or no way of knowing if doctors called their names inaudibly from a distance.  
In warm summer weather, a drinks machine which many - most? - trying to use it seemed to be unsuccessful, feels inadequate when a simple drinking water font would seem like a basic provision for sick/injured people - even more with relatives/friends deterred. Dehydration risk surely?  
As time went on, there was a feeling of a basically disorganised set-up with no one in charge and loads of people milling about, including more and more ambulance people and paramedics, and sick/old people looking very forlorn and lost. I felt so sorry for them but, apart from offering seats, I and others could not help. I don't think I saw a porter or anyone doing any portering over the several hours.  
On the screen, I'd also noticed that 'ambulance arrivals in past hour' were now at Zero. I don't know if that was a good or a bad thing?  
Thankfully, as I'd not eaten and avoided liquids, as abdominal pain on urinating was one of my symptoms, and I'd not done so since waking that day, plus wanted to be able to urinate if any sample needed later by a doctor, I did not use a toilet but couldn't avoid hearing lots of grumbles about same.  
My eventual liaison with a doctor was a rapid-fire series of questions where I had to ask if I could be allowed time to actually answer them - including toilet problems, notably saying I'd not urinated since getting-up that day - which I don't think went down too well, and cursory exam, with instruction to insist on seeing my GP in person, an instruction which was repeated when I asked the doctor how to do that as a just a patient, which was met by something to the effect of 'do you know the way out OK?'.  
That treatment area was actually quiet, unlike the waiting area, which was very busy as I gingerly exited and gently sat down on a step outside.  
All in all, the experience was grim. I really feel for hard-working, hard-pressed nurses, assistants and junior doctors doing their best in such an environment, but also wondered if any actually complain or don't just organise and tell management they're not putting up with it anymore? Who manages the place outside of the clinical area?  
But I felt and feel most sorry for those vulnerable people left to their fate in such an environment with no one to speak up for them. It's beyond cruel.  
PS: whatever happened to the modern, roomy new ED/A&E in the shiny new-build?

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Dsapatient
title: The journey to terminal cancer
body:
I have suffered from COPD for perhaps four years, this May I was invited to the COPD clinic for the annual review. I had been suffering from headaches and a back pain. My doctor was called about the results and I was informed should the pains I was experiencing in my back return, I was advised to take myself to A & E or even call an ambulance. Appointments would be arranged for me at the Cardiac and Urology departments.  
In mid June my daughter arrived at my home and within a couple of hours I found myself in The Victoria Hospital Kirkcaldy A & E, quite a long queue but it seemed to be reducing quite quickly. Triage nurse was very efficient and had me checked out recorded and passed to the doctor. In the Admissions department I had X-ray, ECG, the usual BP, oxygen and pulse repeatedly and informed that was being admitted. Must be something wrong, this COPD has gotten serious. Soon enough I was in an admissions ward for the night, thank goodness the reports on the Telly about waiting around in corridors was false at least here in Kirkcaldy.  
A couple of days in Admissions and another trip to the X-ray and MRI department to have a scan with contrast, then I was informed a move was imminent and a bed was becoming vacant in ward 23. Oops this is a Cardiologist ward. I was duly visited by several doctors all curious about my reason for self medication of oxygen I had acquired online to help my COPD, it helps a bit with energy loss. Anyway the outcome is I should be in ward 43 the Respiratory ward. Dr Fairbairn had me brought up to ward 43 to the treatment room where his magic pen produced a porridge like substance in three containers from my back which he would send away for analysis, the results would be back in a few days and in the meantime I would return to ward 23. I was in the wrong place as my ECG results indicated that my heart was strong and in ok condition. This is despite having an MI (myocardial infarction) some 30 years ago.  
Regrettably it was time to leave this ward who have I must admit have been great, nurses and doctorâ€™s alike Iâ€™ve been promoted up to respiratory Ward 43. Another X-ray and Scan with contrast.  
The following day I meet Dr Lee who will be going to fit a drain in the plura which is a sack around the left lung in my case. He will also put a tube with a camera with the facility of retrieving biopsyâ€™s in the area. He will stitch up the hole but leave drain tube, I could be on medication and oxygen for sometime. Fine I thought no problem there.  
Next day the porter arrived and to take me to the operations waiting area a nurse referred the area as the recovery room. The team with Dr Lee consisted of two others plus an observer a young man from Ward 43.  
I remember some tapping going on on my back then nothing more. Apparently I was in there an hour but it didnâ€™t seem like that and I was quite tired when I got back to the ward. I was receiving pain killers in the form of paracetamol and alternately oral morphine seemed a good idea but I had no pain, with that the morphine stopped, these medical people know whatâ€™s required.  
I had now been in hospital for 9 days and was feeling much better. Along the way I had received an additional medication to reduce the swelling in my ankles which was referred as water retention, this medication causes one to go to the toilet quite a lot in the afternoon. So now I know the heart is good no need for trip to Cardiology and the water retention medication is working wonders with the urine so no need for a trip to the Urologists. Just a case of getting this fluid out of the plura and perhaps thatâ€™s the COPD also taken care of.  
On the 10th day I have the drainage removed from the operation and the pipe remains for the district nurses to take over draining this Plura. A meeting has been arranged before I am discharged with Dr Fairbairn and clinical nurse specialist Ed.  
At this point I am about to find out whatâ€™s the results of the analysis on that porridge Dr Fairbairn removed some days ago.  
Not good news the reported results that the material is untreatable cancer cells. No treatment from either radiotherapy or chemotherapy, there would be a possibility of immunotherapy dependent on the report on the biopsyâ€™s taken earlier but most likely the results have got to be greater than 50/50  
Well so much for my worries about COPD.  
My Doctor assured me I had a clear X-ray 18 months ago.  
There you have it my journey from COPD and a breathing problem to being told I have an untreatable cancer and an estimated prognosis of 7 months. All in the short space of 10 days.  
In this 10 days I must say I have met with some outstanding people in the NHS, the A & E departments, the Admissions doctors and nurses, ward 23 where I was made welcome and looked after, Ward 43 with their Efficient nursing staff and Doctors including Dr Fairbairn and Dr Lee. Now my appreciation goes to the lovely young ladies from the district nurses office in Rosyth, Audrey. Amy, Emily & Karen, so efficient and smart.  
Trust the process these people are professional even to the settling down again at home, my doctors surgery informed, the DWP informed and benefits arranged, oxygen supply arranged, and Ed is available to relieve any fears or worries.  
Thank you and God bless.

title: Medication Problem
body: Needed to get my medication urgently before going on an emergency trip abroad.  The Practice were great at helping me get my prescription.  One less thing to worry about!

title: Great practice
body: I called to make an appointment and was told that if I made my way I could be seen, the GP waited for me, she was lovely as usual and reassured me regarding my health issue.

title: Very responsive GP practice
body: The office staff, GPs and nurses are all very helpful and responsive to questions, queries and requests.

title: Friendly & Efficient Service
body: Phoned in for a routine medication review, was booked in for an appointment two days later, can't complain about that. Thanks

title: Excellent care
body: I just wanted to leave some feedback regarding my recent experience with woodlands health centre over the last few months. I have been struggling with my mental health and I have been able to get appointments really quickly which have been vital to my recovery. The doctors have been so thorough and caring which has really helped reassure me. I have also the surgery to help complete some paperwork for an insurance claim and although this has taken a while to do the doctor called me on a Saturday to talk through and was again very thorough and helpful in assisting me with this. All you seem to hear is how much the nhs is struggling and whilst I donâ€™t doubt that is the case, my experience with woodlands has not reflected that at all. Thanks to all the doctors and staff!

title: A traditional caring practice
body:
I would like to thank all of the staff at Isca medical practice regarding my recent treatment which was exceptional in all areas when I can in to difficult times with my health. 
Everyone was so professional and helpful I can honestly not recommend this practice enough.

author: Kngbob
title: Lack of communication to the family
body: My dad has had 3 surgeries in 2 months, last surgery amputation. We all feel disappointed in the lack of communication between Doctor and family. There has been no real contact to update family on my fathers health and care. For the last 3 weeks we werenâ€™t allowed in to visit due to covid. As a family we were always masked entering hospital and the virus was brought into the ward through a patient admission. After this we have had 2 phone calls from nurses to update us. Trying to contact the ward takes on average 40 minute as phones are not being answered. Family need this contact to find out how loved ones are, and this is not being done at present as no-one seems to answer the phones.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

title: Professional friendly staff
body:
I had to have a scan after a fall at home. All the staff were considerate, professional and helpful.
I was not kept waiting for an inordinate time and was kept informed of what was happening.
The young doctor I saw and the nurse that tried to stop my head bleeding were just two of the great team that I saw.

author: Lansdowne
title: Cancer physio session - give exercise a try it helps
body:
Returning home after lung cancer diagnosis, received my radiation treatment few weeks later. After my treatment I was feeling tired ,depressed and very low, I was asked by my consultant to take part in a home physio programme this was the last thing on my mind.  
12weeks later I have completed my programme and feel a lot better in myself, the programme was on line and I didnâ€™t have to leave my home and instructor was caring and enquired about my ability to train each week. I even find myself doing the exercises when sitting throughout the week at home.  
Give exercise a try it helps and you feel you having support from being part of the group.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: authenticwq59
title: North west phlebotomy service
body:
I was referred by my GP to get some blood taken at a hub in Plean street today.  
Getting bloods taken is a very traumatic and I spent the whole night worrying and even got myself so worked up before my appointment that I sat in tears in the waiting area.  
The nurse Kimberley called me in and made sure I was very relaxed and comfortable. She checked all my details and was aware that I was dreading the next part. She talked me through it all step by step making sure that at any point if I wanted her to stop she would instantly.  
However through her talking me through it and keeping me distracted with small chat it was over and done before I knew it and I never felt a thing! I was so relieved to have such a talented, friendly and effortless nurse make my appointment bearable. I was overwhelmed with joy as I can be difficult to bleed hence my apprehension but I cannot fault the girl at all.  
I would definitely be comfortable enough going back to get my bloods done after this experience. It's people like her that make the NHS service. I just wanted to make sure that her work didn't go unnoticed.

author: Yshd
title: Brilliant care - patient safety concern
body:
On admission to the Day Case Ward the greeting was lovely and you're made to feel welcomed by the reception team.  
It was quite relaxed and people were advised that because of the heatwave happening they could step out for a breath of fresh air. Theatre staff and anaesthetists were brilliant. Again easing any nerves.  
On return from theatre whilst caring, the staff didnâ€™t seem to recognise the need for ensuring safety of a patient well enough. I can speak up for myself but for someone who couldnâ€™t you could left isolated in the toilet with no call bell near you. I couldnâ€™t reach the call bell if I felt faint.  
Also there was no toilet paper and I couldnâ€™t call for anyone to assist me. This does seem to be a common thread in care for a person that you can be left alone in a toilet with no ability to call for help. It has happened to me before. Other than that the overall care was perfect.

author: Firzw87
title: Birth at the Royal Infirmary Edinburgh
body:
I had my son in December 2021, starting in the midwife led unit at Simpson Maternity and moving to the labour suite as complications developed.  
Things started well and I found the midwife led unit absolutely lovely, with the one exception that the birth pool was out of action. I felt safe and calm in the room and the midwives brought tea and toast. My birth plan was read and followed as far as was possible, with midwives guiding me on interventions and pain relief as well as being very encouraging when I hit a few really difficult and low points. However I was in labour for a very long time and as a result I ended up with a forceps delivery, which was my worst nightmare before I went into labour, and at the time I was so frightened.  
The critical thing for me, that helped what could have been a really traumatic birth be actually fine was the staff. At all times I felt respected, listened to and cared for, in particular by my two midwives (shift change!). The doctor who finally delivered my son was also incredible. We had a follow up appointment a few weeks later with him where he explained what had happened and why which also made a huge difference to how I felt about the birth.  
On the ward after the birth all the staff were again lovely, patient and helpful, but Iâ€™ll be honest, I think they were short staffed and were not always available when needed for example in the night. I think more staff to help with simple tasks such as passing the baby for women who couldnâ€™t get out of bed, bringing tea and water, and showing how to do basics like change nappies would have made a big difference and keeps midwives a bit freer to help with things like breastfeeding or medical concerns.  
Overall I think I had a very positive experience in difficult circumstances, especially as covid restrictions were in place again at the time. I know the NHS is under huge pressure but I am hugely grateful to those who delivered my son for their kindness and professionalism.

author: waterkp83
title: Discharged without informing family
body:
My father arrived to the Accident and Emergency department by ambulance. He is known to suffer with diagnosed mental health issues, these issues sadly brought him to overdose as an attempt to commit suicide, stating the voices in his head were getting too much and was actively asking for help. We thought this would finally be the first step in him getting help. I explained everything to the doctor in A&E at the time, my phone number was given and I was advised I would be told of any updates.  
The following day, I arrived at 12:00pm to be told that my father had been discharged an hour earlier with a bus pass to get home.  
My father had nothing on him apart from the clothes on his back and slippers on his feet. He did not have the keys to his home, any way to contact family, any money on him or even a proper pair of shoes on his feet. Aware that he was mentally unstable and still in a state of wanting to commit suicide, I asked why the department thought this was acceptable just to be told that they are sorry.  
Is this normal protocol from the NHS? I am appalled and disgusted at how my father has been abandoned in a time of need.

author: Niamh
title: Helpful around work commitments
body:
I received therapy from Inclusion Thurrock with Rebecca. This is the third time that I have attended therapy with Rebecca and once again, the care I received was excellent. I was able to join the sessions remotely, which was helpful around work commitments.  
Rebecca listened in full to my issues, drew on her previous experience of working with me to understand these and helped me to develop effective techniques for recovering.  
When going to therapy for the first time or returning to therapy, it can feel daunting and embarrassing to talk about all your issues, but Rebecca put my mind at rest and I felt at ease to be completely open, which enabled me to really get to the heart of my issues and work through them. Although it's necessary to talk about the things that are causing distress, Rebecca has a way of making this feel much easier and lighter than I would have expected it to be.  
This experience has helped me enormously and I'm so grateful for the care I've received.

author: Rose Mc Hugh
title: Brilliant Life Coach
body:
I walked out of a job in late January of this year, I had been feeling low as I've a history of depression. I then applied for Universal Credit. With being off work and effects of covid I became more isolated and my confidence plummeted.  
However I received a telephone call from Lucia from Condition Management Programme (CMP) and can never thank her enough for that phone call. She chatted to me probably longer than her allocated time span, and it was a turning point for me.  
I can't remember everything Lucia said to me but I do know I was able to see that I had it in me to get another job and if I didn't I could start going out and start to regain my confidence. She put my name down for next course of CMP and she phoned me again just to check on me.  
I can't thank Lucia enough she is truly a brilliant coach, no nonsense person who I call an earth angel. I'm sure there are many who are indebted to her.  
I was unable to attend her course due to fact that I am was working.  
Yes I'm now working and loving it and living again and can never thank Lucia enough for that phone call and her call yesterday to see how I was getting on and to sign me off. Even yesterday Lucia gave me further numbers to ensure that I'll not slip again.  
Lucia is a complete asset and I'm sure doesn't even realise how many people like myself she helps. Not only is she a brilliant Life Coach she also a really lovely approachable person and all I can say is a thank you Lucia for that phone call.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: ospreymb44
title: Care for my mum
body:
We needed support quickly for my mum who is 93. It was reassuring to speak with Lisa and her colleague.  
The carers were lovely and provided excellent, compassionate care.

author: Lesley22
title: A virtual visit
body:
I was able to have a virtual visit with my mum today!  I cannot tell you how grateful I am for this experience.  I live in the States and the virtual visit allowed me to see my mum, to visit with her, and be at her bedside.  It was so good to be able to chat with her, just like I was there! ðŸ¥°
The staff made the virtual booking easy!  They sent me a link, Helen connected us and a facilitator took me to my mums bedside.  Helen even followed up with another email and asked me if I wanted another visit! ðŸ’•
The staff is amazing and I truly appreciate the experience!ðŸ’•ðŸ¥°ðŸ’•

author: romeoff58
title: The staff are capable and definitely eager to assist us
body:
I have been involved in varying levels of commitment with inclusion for the best part of 20 years. Whilst during that time many things have changed, often due to budgeting on changing local politics and funding but my recent experience is reassuring as the level of service available and quality of it has never been better.  
I find that the staff are all well qualified and focused on providing the most effective treatment options in line with whatever is available and appropriate. Obviously some clients only engage because it is a requirement of things like probation or retaining their script. Lately it does appear that the other service users are all engaging because they, like me, are now at a point where just going through the motions achieves nothing.  
For those who genuinely seek long term change, the staff are more than capable and definitely eager to assist us (clients) in our efforts to work the ongoing programmes and work towards a place of change.

author: zuluwp43
title: I was completely happy with the service
body: I was completely happy with the service I had from the Matron - feel better for her visits - a very caring person and I feel I knew her for ages. I cannot say I have any suggestions to add to the service provided. I thank you for your help it is much appreciated.

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Doctors explain everything
body: My care has been pretty good so far and Iâ€™m honestly happy enough with the care just wish I could get my discharges soon as possible. He doctors have been amazing and I can say thanks to them I have recovered a lot and am starting to feel a lot better. They always explain tests and updates which makes me updated and allows me to see my road to recovery. The nurses have been brilliant in making me feel so much better as they are so kind and constantly checking up on me has made it so much easier. The food and cleaning has been amazing and I have had no issues so far

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Great maternity experience
body: The Midwife who delivered my baby deserves a Gold medal she was quick to attend to myself in labour. Considering my birthing plan had not yet been done she responded to all my requests and was very patient and reassuring with me due to being in pain! I Had a safe delivery ( natural birth) and Will definitely recommend the birthing suit especially because it is private and feels like a safe place! I had my baby on one of the hottest days of the year and was not affected due to how well the hospital itself was ventilated with air conditioning! Meals were provided and the staff was very welcoming and always knocking to see if baby was ok and if I needed anything. Also the suite I stayed in overnight was nice it had a double bed which allows your partner to sleep beside you! Overall I give 5 star rating considering everyone tried to tell me the hospital was not great especially for maternity I can vouch that this is not the case from my own experience so happy I did not listen to the negativity.

author: jazzsc38
title: Life changing care
body:
I am very late to post this, but having just found this website i would like to pass on my thanks to Dr Brady and Dr Watkins at Glasgow Royal Infirmary Outpatients Dept.  
During my early 20s i suffered from severe hypertension and was subsequently put on multiple bloody pressure medications for this and was also diagnosed with LV hypertrophy as a result. I was warned umpteen times not to fall pregnant as it would be dangerous for me. I also suffered lots of side effects from these medications and felt unwell for years. My care was transferred to the GRI in my 30s where i was seen by Dr Brady who discovered i had FMD in my renal artery which was causing the hypertension. I was then placed under the care of Dr Watkins who suggested an angioplasty and stent to attempt to treat this (i was informed this is not guaranteed to work). I was very lucky and the procedure cured my high blood pressure. I no longer need to take any medication for my blood pressure and am delighted to say i have recently had a healthy baby. I am seen annually for checkups and every time am treated with care, dignity and respect. I will never be able to thank Dr Watkins and Dr Brady enough for all the care i have been given from them and for the huge improvement in my life as a result.

title: Brilliant
body: Friendly, informative and the procedure I was booked in for went very smooth. Felt at ease and any nerves were dealt with in a professional manner

title: Outstanding Practice
body: I have been registered with the Nightingale Practice for over ten years. I have had a lot of interaction with the service. I've always received an appointment quickly and been extremely satisfied with the care I've received. I would highly recommend the Nightingale Practice.

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Staff are kind
body: I have been treated very well in the hospital and have honestly been so happy with all the care that I have received from the staff. The nurses are so good and are absolute lovely. Their kindness given has been incredible and the fact the constant. The doctors have been absolutely fine and have taken time to explain everything to me which is something I am so thankful for. The food has verb very nice I do enjoy it which I cannot complain about. I have had no sues and am grateful for everything

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Excellent care and kindness
body: I had recent experience of a telephone consultation and a face to face visit.  Although it can be tricky to get through I managed and was offered an appointment very quickly. The care and kindness shown to me when I was feeling awful was just brilliant and made such a difference. All the staff from the receptionist to the GPs and nurse taking blood were very professional and very helpful.  I am very grateful.

title: blood test
body: i went for my blood test today and the nurse  who took it  was amazing. amazing bed side manor really nice and amazing sense of humour which made feel so relaxed and calm. the nurse is a an asset to the the team.

title: brilliant practice
body: All staff are friendly, helpful and go the extra mile. Doctors are attentive to everything you feel the need to say and have always been very thorough. Can't fault anyone, anything.

title: extremely good practice
body: As a patient I have found everyone at the practice extremely helpful and attentive. Diagnosis of my little aliments have been spot on and treatment is working. I have every confidence in the Chiltern House practice.

author: castorer78
title: Beyond the call of duty
body: My experience from the staff was not a great experience as I came through A+E and it was clear to me that I had had a stroke but the staff member in Triage was rude and abrupt, asked me if I had ever heard of Bell's Palsy to which I replied no. All they had checked was my blood pressure. Eventually got through to see a stroke specialist who clarified that I had definitely had had a stroke and referred me over to the acute admissions ward. This is when things started to change and the whole attitude I was getting was beginning to change as It was recognized by a specialist. Eventually I was moved up to the stroke ward at Crosshouse where the care and consideration I have been given has at times gone beyond the call of duty. The Nurses are dedicated to their work and take patients concerns very seriously. I am getting home today purely because the Dr & Nurses were experienced.

author: errandzc47
title: Have always had excellent treatment
body: With surgery, I have always had excellent treatment and much consideration. And Doctor Goel is certainly my favorite doctor ever and the medical staff are always excellent and helpful.

title: Psychological Wellbeing Practitioner
body: Great sessions provided by the practitioner - very impressed with the level of service offered by NHS. Had sessions for health anxiety and they turned out to be very beneficial.

readBy.name: South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust

author: Jomic
title: Thanking all those involved in extending my life
body:
I received a bowel cancer test kit through the post in November 2021 as part of the NHS surveillance process, after deliberating for a few days I eventually made use and dispatched for analysis.  
Within a couple of weeks I was contacted by a bowel cancer specialist nurse and my journey began. Following several extended phone interviews and a great deal of anxiety and sleepless nights, I subsequently had two colonoscopies followed by bowel surgery at York hospital.  
The medical teams at York were, on all three occasions, exceptionally caring and patient focused, I cannot praise enough those who helped me get through the most challenging experience of my life so far.  
The exceptionally kind Doctor who discovered the cancer, the nurse who talked to me all the way through my first procedure. Sam, the cancer care nurse who explained my situation going forward, the nurse who made eye to eye contact and comforted me during anaesthesia preparation in theatre, the anaesthetist who understood my needle phobia, Mr. Di Benedetto who skilfully removed the growth, the ward nurses who dealt with the aftermath of my reaction to the anaesthetic and helped me begin to walk the path to recovery. I am here in July 2022 thanking all those involved in extending my life. Thank you.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Extremely efficient care.
body:
Having found myself collapsed on the bathroom floor, during the night, (I am 76 years old,) my husband called 999, the first time in his life.
I was attended by two extremely caring paramedics, who thoroughly checked me over before given us advise, as we were  travelling home to Kent later that day. They reassured not only myself but also my husband who was very shocked at finding me. We continued home, following the advice given to us, on the hottest day of the year and am pleased to say that I have fully recovered. It would appear I had suffered a bout of dysentery! Our sincere thanks to the two gentlemen.

author: waltzjk49
title: Continue the good work (10/10).
body:
I attended A+E with high blood pressure. (shocked). I was well cared for from the beginning. I was a long time in A+E, not the fault of my doctors or nurses as I was very efficiently dealt with. It was waiting for bloods and waiting for my blood pressure to go down.  
The following morning I attended the Day Care ward 1. Again was efficiently dealt with and was impressed by Doctor and Nurses. I am still in their care with follow - up tests, Ultrasound, scans etc. Continue the good work.(10/10)

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Great staff
body: Thank you to the Doctor who saw me Sat night/ Sun morning. A&E are clearly understaffed 7hrs to be seen! When finally seen, the doctor was very professional, caring and took time to treat me. The staff are great, but we need more on duty.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

title: Nurse in white top Accident and emergency  aboveâ€¦
body: Accident and emergency lady in white top shift finished at 7 am today thank you to nurse with a white top uniform,  name began with m miffy calmed me talked to me thank you,  Iâ€™m feeling less anxious thank you lady M Iâ€™m so grateful I know it will be better for my family if Iâ€™m having a gd day u have made that happen

title: Nothing to worry about
body: Not having had cataract surgery before, I was rather nervous as to what to expect. As it turned out, everything went well - the staff were great, everything was explained and I need not have worried at all. If you need cataracts doing , go for it.

title: Brilliant receptionist
body: I rang this morning to ask for advise as I have a bad case of covid. The receptionist couldnâ€™t have been more helpful and supportive. What a kind lady. Well done brewer street.

author: jazzsc38
title: Fantastic care
body:
My husband and I would like to send on our thanks to all of the staff at Crosshouse Maternity Unit. Having suffered from previous miscarraiges we were extremely anxious when I became pregnant and experienced a few scares throughout my pregnancy  
We visited EPAS a few times initially and later the Day Care and Out of Hours unit for scans and checkups. The care we received was first class and every member of staff treated us with understanding, respect and dignity. We were absolutely terrified we would lose our baby but everyone who looked after us was incredibly caring and helped massively to reassure us and keep us calm.  
After a failed induction I was taken for a C Section. The theatre staff were absolutely amazing, they each introduced themselves and thoroughly explained the surgery prior to, and also throughout the procedure. Athough I'm sure they must deliver thousands of babies, every one of them made ours feel like 'the first'. They all made it such an enjoyable experience for us.  
We will never be able to explain how grateful we are to you all but hope you know how wonderful each and every one of you are and what a positive impact you had on our journey.  
Our baby boy arrived safely and healthy.  
Thank you so much!

The nurses have been incredible like you honestly could not beat a single thing about them. They are so kind and I am so happy with everything that I have seen with them. The food and cleaning has been very good and I am very happy with it. I have had no issues with my care and am very happy with it all.

author: The Old Bat
title: My 2nd scan
body:
This was my 2nd scan, the last one was 6 years ago, delayed because of the Pandemic.  
The staff were lovely, the young man who carried out the whole procedure was still training, His 'boss' joined us when it came to the actual scan and I agreed for a work experience young man to be present too.  
Everything was explained very clearly and carefully. I was treated very kindly, with respect and with understanding of any pain I was experiencing. Each element of the process was explained as we went along and I was continually checked with to see if I was ok. There was also humour and a very good atmosphere in the room and I rather enjoyed it. I highly commend the staff they were excellent.

author: junegr37
title: Engaging online groups
body: I enjoyed the online groups and was surprised at how engaging they were and the content of them. Also the professionals of the hosts, Grant and Jason was clear and the experience they brought with them was clear too. I felt confident that they genuinely had not just mine but the whole groups best interests in mind and were well aware that people bring with them complex and complicated histories and personal problems. If any of us raised our own concerns or maybe appeared to be struggling with issues I feel confident that extra support would be available and offered. The content of the groups was all pertinent to rehab. The groups were well delivered in an appropriate way and homework assignments were relevant and essentially an extension of the groups that helped me increase my personal understanding of rehab and what it means. Overall, I found it very inclusive, that it fostered a sense of belonging and purpose and did help prepare me for rehab. I do now understand what will be expected of me and what to expect from rehab and I am very grateful for the opportunity. I'd score it a 9 out of 10 if asked. Very little to fault and an interesting and informative set of groups.

Excellent service, I felt calm during the whole experience.  
Thank you so much ladies.

title: Investigation
body:
I was very nervous about my appointment at Boston Pilgrim hospital first for an ultrasound then ward 1B for a hysteroscopy, but all the staff made me very relaxed. They were so reassuring and their manner very friendly.  
They all explained exactly the procedures they were going to do and how I could stop at any time if uncomfortable.

body: Went to clinic for 6 monthly hiv care. The staff, services and facilities were good.

My dad was taken into Emergency Dept Monklands Hospital.  
Despite it being extremely busy was seen promptly and had excellent care.  
He is still recovering in hospital,  
Thanks very much for his care.

author: local resident
title: Attendance at A&E on a busy Friday evening
body: Went to A&E on a Friday evening after a severe dizzy spell that I feared could be a forewarning of something much more serious. Although it was exceptionally busy with 192 patients waiting to be seen, I was impressed with the care and attention received. Staff were professional, efficient and reassuring. They attended to all patients with courtesy and kindness. Infants were attended to speedily as you would expect and I feel that ESH A&E did well in difficult circumstances.

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: They are so helpful
body:
Accident and emergency was stressful to me since I was bringing my daughter in. It was a stressful situation altogether. I am glad how nice everyone down there was and understanding of how to handle me stressing.  
Daisy ward is very good, it is bright and colourful. It is spacious for my daughter to play in when she is feeling a bit better. The rooms are so modern the air-con, TV, en-suite and even the rooms being individual. This is so much better than a ward as you do not keep anyone up and it is so much nicer to have that privacy with a sick child. The level of care is outstanding.  
The staff have been nothing but nice, they are so helpful. They keep me updated regularly with my daughterâ€™s health and what they are going to do. I am happy with everything here.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: The staff are so kind hearted
body:
Daisy ward has been a dream, the cleanliness of the place and constantly seeing cleaners helps ease the mind with covid cases rising again. The room is nice and I am glad of the privacy, they are so accommodating with putting a bed and everything down so I can lie on it. I like the way they offer tea and toast it is a nice gesture.  
The staff are so kind hearted and they must love their jobs with how they carry themselves. They are a credit to the NHS, they always sound so full of life and nothing will bring them down.  
I am more than happy to have brought my daughter here.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: The staff are something else, nothing is a bother for them
body:
Accident and emergency was okay, we were triaged straight away but then had a bit of waiting about to do. I was happy to wait though as long as my son got sorted.  
Daisy ward has been very good, I cannot complain about anything. The level of care my son is receiving is excellent and I can see him improving. The environment is good the place is new and fresh.  
The staff are something else, nothing is a bother for them. You feel as though your child is the only one there because of the attention he receives and the amount of times they check on him. They all have such big hearts because this is definitely not an easy job.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

What a fantastic service

author: deltazr59
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Contented in here
body: I am contented in here. I sit in the lounge with all the other people and have a good yarn. The other residents are so friendly. I am very happy here. I like it that my room is on the ground floor. We get lovely meals. My son calls and takes me out for a drive and things like that.

title: Hip op on hottest day
body:
After my hip replacement surgery, I cannot praise the staff enough. From the consultant, his superstar pa, the anaesthetist, surgery staff and Hasland ward staff all were friendly and kind. 
Unfortunately, it was the hottest day of the year and I was not in a good way, 37degrees but there wasn't any aircon or even a single fan on the ward! Throwing up for 5 hours, after surgery, with very low blood pressure in that heat was not  very much fun.
My main concern is that there is such a lack of communication between staff, so much so that I had the same conversation at least 4 times about meds which was still changed at the last minute. I did feel bullied regarding medication even though I had full backing of my consultant. All in all, if there was a bit more cohesive thinking, this hospital would be great, the staff are lovely. Maybe new caterers too as the food is dire, I would rather have 1 decent course rather than 3 awful ones.

readBy.name: Chesterfield Royal Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Good practice.
body: Although it can be difficult to get through to the doctors on the phone, I find that the nurses, doctors & receptionists at this practice are very caring, kind & polite. They will help where they can but they are under alot of pressure, I found that they don't rush you when you have an appointment & they genuinely listen to you. So keep doing what you're doing guys.

title: Why have you stopped ear micro suction ?
body:
Overall I have been with the speedwell practice for many years, there have been some great Doctors over the years some no more. Seems I only know a few now and see a different new doctor every time.

I suffer with my ears and learnt you now stop doing ear suctioning? Iâ€™m very sad about this and I have been suffering for over a month with deafness. a lot of my medications keep being rejected too why with no explanation? I give praise throughout lockdown whilst other people complained about their Goâ€™s the speedwell was really on point throughout lockdownâ€¦ itâ€™s now I see change for the worse?

title: Excellent practice
body: Parkview surgery is always available to give same day appointment , I have never been disappointed. Great doctors and staff. I have been with this surgery since 2013,and happy with their service.

title: Out of Date technology
body: I have tried so many times to contact this surgery, the phone system is impossible, first the phone msg is contradictory re Covid advice, secondly you are told you are â€˜xâ€™ in the queue fair enough, half and hour later when get near to the end instead of the msg the phone line rings out - this happens time & time again. There is no online system. We have tried to visit the surgery to make an appointment - not allowed in - just how are we supposed to make an appointment for a non urgent issue. Itâ€™s beyond a joke, in the days of Zoom calls and online booking systems this surgery is behind the times , needs investment to bring it up to scratch.  However the surgery does love to send letters to you to say you havenâ€™t  been in touch to book an appointment, how about save the postage costs buy a phone instead

title: Why Bother To Leave A Review
body:
None of these reviews have been responded to so what is the purpose of them?

There doesn't appear to be any improvement in service and we are now having to put our repeat prescriptions in at least 3 weeks in advance and, most of the time, they are still not ready!

title: Not very good
body:
Been with this practice for over 50 years now but the last few years they've been disappointing.  It's a battle to get past receptionists to see a doctor.  Getting through on the phone is a nightmare, you're either in a queue or have constant ringing with no answer.  Phone up for an appointment at 8am on the dot to see a specific doctor to be told they're fully booked and have to settle for a phone appointment with a doctor I've never spoken to before.  I don't understand why the surgery isn't back to normal face to face appointments and feel that Covid is being used as an excuse to implement and introduce lots of changes which aren't for the better.  Lots of people, me included, find it much easier speaking and explaining issues to a Dr face to face.  Phone appointments are awkward and not ideal especially when living in an area where phone reception isn't very good.  I absolutely dread having to ring for appointments.  It's embarrassing to have to explain to a receptionist what the issue is before being allowed any sort of consultation.  Reception staff often come across as abrupt and rude which is out of order as no one should be made to feel bad when they are ill and need help.  
The surgery needs to be back to running normal face to face appointments without having to jump through hoops to get one and if we have to phone at 8am for an appointment at least make sure there are plenty available.  Baffles me how we're not able to prebook appointments yet when phoning at 8am you eventually get through they've all gone and surgery is fully booked.  How does that happen if you can't prebook?

title: Booking an appointment
body: Have being calling to book for appointment for 3 days now, so the phone keeps ringing for 1hr I was so patient on the phone yet no one is picking, I want to the clinic to the receptionist I meant said he can't book an appointment unless I make a call, so this is frustrating because I need my GP to refer me
